content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose strategy B{B} for several reasons:

1. The game has 75 rounds. This means that in the long run, if the anonymous player is also rational, they will play the dominant strategy that maximizes their own payoff. In this case, the dominant strategy for them would be to pick R, as it guarantees a higher payoff when I choose B.

2. If I pick B and my opponent picks R in each round, I will earn 40$ per round while they earn 0$. Over 75 rounds, that's 300$ more for me than if I had picked R, which would only result in 900$ (since I get 0$ when my opponent picks R and 45$ when we both pick R).

3. The worst-case scenario for me is that we both play R in every round, which means I earn 45$ per round while they earn 40$. Over 75 rounds, this would amount to 2250$ for me and 2100$ for my opponent. However, if I pick B and my opponent picks R, I still come out better with 300$ more than if we both played R.

4. If there's a chance that my opponent might switch strategies in the middle of the game, it would be beneficial to have already earned the maximum possible amount in the first part of the game before any potential strategy shift occurs. In this case, by choosing B, I maximize my earnings early on.

5. It's unlikely that the opponent will stick to R for 75 rounds given the higher returns from picking B when I choose R. Therefore, it makes sense to pick B{B} in order to exploit any potential deviations from the dominant strategy by my opponent.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

As a human player, I would choose strategy R{R} for the following reasons:

1. In the previous round, my opponent chose R while I chose B, which resulted in a higher payoff for me (40$) compared to if we both had chosen R (45$). However, by choosing R now, I can potentially earn 45$ instead of the current 40$.

2. If my opponent continues to choose R, I will still be earning more than they are in each round because I have a higher payoff when they choose R. Over 74 remaining rounds, this could amount to a significant difference in our earnings.

3. It's possible that my opponent might switch their strategy in the future, and by playing R now, I create an opportunity for myself to earn more if they do change their strategy later on.

4. If my opponent continues to play R, the worst-case scenario for me is that we both choose R in every remaining round, resulting in a payoff of 45$ per round for each player. However, even in this case, I would come out better than if I had chosen B throughout the game, as I would have earned an additional 40$ in the first round when my opponent chose R.

5. If there's a chance that my opponent might switch strategies in the middle of the game, it makes sense to continue playing the strategy that has proven beneficial so far (R) and potentially capitalize on any potential deviations from the dominant strategy by my opponent.
